qas.question: What is one possible objection to the theory of integrated variation?

answers.text: often no intermediate forms between closely related species are found

qas.question: Why did Darwin wonder why all of nature isn't chaotic and random?

answers.text: why, if species have descended from other species by insensibly fine gradations, do we not everywhere see innumerable transitional forms?

qas.question: What did Darwin ultimately decide was the reason that nature is not a chaos of variation?

answers.text: the competition between different forms, combined with the small number of individuals of intermediate forms, often leading to extinction of such forms.

context: Chapter VI begins by saying the next three chapters will address possible objections to the theory, the first being that <a0_0>often no intermediate forms between closely related species are found<a0_0/>, though the theory implies such forms must have existed. As Darwin noted, "Firstly, <a1_0>why, if species have descended from other species by insensibly fine gradations, do we not everywhere see innumerable transitional forms?<a1_0/> Why is not all nature in confusion, instead of the species being, as we see them, well defined?" Darwin attributed this to <a2_0>the competition between different forms, combined with the small number of individuals of intermediate forms, often leading to extinction of such forms.<a2_0/> This difficulty can be referred to as the absence or rarity of transitional varieties in habitat space.
